item.title: Trump Backing for Nippon Steel Deal Comes With Big Questions
item.description: After more than 17 months of lobbying and close-fought negotiations to secure control of United States Steel Corp., Japan’s Nippon Steel Corp. appeared on Friday to have received a presidential blessing.
item.dc:creator: Clara Ferreira Marques

media:content.media:description: The United States Steel Corp. Clairton Coke Works along the banks of the Monongahela River in Clairton, Pennsylvania, US, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2023. US Steel surged after it rejected a takeover offer from rival Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. to create one of the world's biggest steelmakers, and said it will begin a review of its strategic options instead.

item.title: Record India Private Credit Deal Hinges on Tricky Collateral
item.description: On the surface, India’s record-breaking private credit deal is a milestone for the market.
item.dc:creator: Nic Querolo, Saikat Das, Divya Patil

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of Shapoorji Pallonji Group in Mumbai on May 14.

item.title: Five Key Charts to Watch in Global Commodity Markets This Week
item.description: Chicken is going to be harder to come by in markets from China to Europe after a case of bird flu was detected in top exporter Brazil. Summer is just around the corner in the Northern Hemisphere, prompting forecasts for hurricanes as well as predictions about gasoline demand in the US. And the Democratic Republic of the Congo — dubbed the “Saudi Arabia of cobalt” — is becoming a player in the trade war between China and the US.
item.dc:creator: Simar Khanna

media:content.media:description: ISA Brown chickens in a chicken coop at an egg farm in Mason, Michigan, US, on Monday, March 3, 2025. Egg prices have soared to a record of over $8 a dozen, driven by the worst-ever outbreak of avian flu in the US and contributing to broader inflation pressures.

item.title: Treasury Traders Enter Abridged Week With Inflation Top of Mind
item.description: Weary bond investors enter a holiday-shortened week facing fresh US inflation readings at a time when consumers are already anticipating steeper prices pressures given President Donald Trump’s tariff plans.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick

item.title: Banco BPM Appeals Italy Regulator’s Delay of UniCredit Bid
item.description: Banco BPM SpA is seeking to block Italy’s market regulator from delaying a proposed takeover of the bank by UniCredit SpA, as part of an escalating legal battle over the deal.
item.dc:creator: Sonia Sirletti, Vernon Silver

media:content.media:description: A Banco BPM SpA bank branch in Milan, Italy, on Friday, Nov. 29, 2024. The Italian government is examining ways to counter UniCredit SpA’s unsolicited takeover bid for smaller Italian rival Banco BPM.

item.title: Long-Bond Revolt Pressures 60/40 Comeback in Chaotic 2025 Market
item.description: A slump in the US long bond is clouding the comeback of a classic investment strategy.
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie, Liz Capo McCormick, Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Federal Reserve officials held interest rates steady for a third-straight meeting and emphasized they see a growing risk of both higher inflation and rising unemployment.

item.title: Shipping Bottlenecks in Europe Send a Warning Signal to US, Asia
item.description: Port congestion is worsening at key gateways in northern Europe and other hubs, according to a new report which suggests trade wars could spread maritime disruptions to Asia and the US and push up shipping rates.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

media:content.media:description: The container terminal at Bremerhaven port in Bremerhaven, Germany, on April 22, 2025.

item.title: Elusive Peace Hits Ukraine’s Bonds While Neighbor Markets Surge
item.description: One of the most popular emerging-market trades around Donald Trump’s return to the White House is stumbling.
item.dc:creator: Andras Gergely, Jorgelina Do Rosario

item.title: What’s Happening in EM: Ukraine Bond Trade Loses Steam (Podcast)
item.description: Andras Gergely talks with Zijia Song about how one of the hottest emerging markets trades from earlier this year is now losing steam, as the hopes for a rapid Ukraine peace deal dim.
item.dc:creator: Zijia Song

item.title: China, Indonesia Sovereign Wealth Funds Boost Investment Ties
item.description: China and Indonesia agreed to step up ties between their economies during Premier Li Qiang’s visit to Jakarta, including one on investment involving their sovereign wealth funds.

media:content.media:description: Indonesia's President Prabowo Subianto (L) and Chinese Premier Li Qiang inspect a guard of honour during a welcoming ceremony at the Presidential Palace in Jakarta on May 25, 2025. (Photo by YASUYOSHI CHIBA / AFP) (Photo by YASUYOSHI CHIBA/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Canada’s CDPQ to Invest More Than $10 Billion in UK, FT Says
item.description: Canadian pension fund Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec is looking at investing more than £8 billion ($10.8 billion) in the UK over the coming five years, the Financial Times reported.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Tian Tong Lee

item.title: Softbank’s Son Proposes US-Japan Sovereign Wealth Fund, FT Says
item.description: SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son has proposed setting up a US-Japan sovereign wealth fund aimed at making large investments in technology and infrastructure, the Financial Times reported, citing three unidentified people close to the situation.
item.dc:creator: Yi Wei Wong

media:content.media:description: Masayoshi Son Photographer: Kosuke Okahara/Bloomberg

item.title: Australia’s East Coast Begins Flood Cleanup as Waters Recede
item.description: Australia has drafted in emergency service teams from across the nation to help with clean-up operations after devastating floods in the eastern state of New South Wales.
item.dc:creator: Michael Heath

media:content.media:description: Residents clean a flood-damaged house at Glenthorne on May 24, 2025 in Taree. Photo by Roni Bintang/Getty Images)

item.title: Fed to Take in Stride Another Month of Tame Inflation
item.description: The Federal Reserve may take comfort that tariffs have yet to materially boost official inflation readings, but policymakers will continue to suggest interest rates are on hold until they better understand the coming impact of US trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. Stocks soared after President Donald Trump said he’d pause some tariffs on dozens of countries for 90 days, signaling a tentative reprieve in trade hostilities that has wiped out trillions from global markets and ignited fears of a US recession.

item.title: Junkiest Junk Is Offering a Warning Sign for Debt
item.description: For much of the year, money managers have embraced optimism and snatched up corporate bonds, sending valuations to ever more expensive levels. Now, Wall Street titans are saying it’s time to focus on how bad things can get.
item.dc:creator: Josyana Joshua, Eliza Ronalds-Hannon, Caleb Mutua

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Biggest Wartime Exchange of Prisoners
item.description: Ukraine and Russia began the biggest prisoner exchange since the start of the full-scale invasion in 2022, even as Moscow resists efforts for a ceasefire. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Monsoon’s Earliest Onset in India Since 2009 Boosts Crop Outlook
item.description: The monsoon, a weather phenomenon that waters more than half of India’s farmland, reached the subcontinent before the usual time, boosting crop outlook and raising hopes the nation will lift remaining curbs on exports of farm goods.
item.dc:creator: Atul Prakash, Ashutosh Joshi

media:content.media:description: Workers wear raincoats at a farm in Karnataka, India, on May 23.

item.title: Turkish Central Bank Tightens Screws on Cheap Lira Window Abroad
item.description: Turkey’s central bank raised the reserve requirement ratios on banks’ short term liabilities abroad in a bid to discourage local banks from seeking cheap lira from offshore markets.
item.dc:creator: Baris Balci, Beril Akman

media:content.media:description: Electronic boards display Turkish lira rates at currency exchange bureaus in Bodrum, Turkey, on Thursday, July 6, 2023. The lira has lost 28% of its value so far this year, the biggest decline among 31 major currencies tracked by Bloomberg, after the Argentine peso. Photographer: Moe Zoyari/Bloomberg

item.title: Indonesia to Cut Transport and Power Prices to Spur Consumption
item.description: Indonesia will cut transport and power costs and deliver other stimulus in June and July in an effort to boost household spending and rekindle economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Prima Wirayani

media:content.media:description: Morning commuters get off a train at Tebet railway station in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Feb. 15, 2024. Indonesian stocks jumped in early trading as traders bet on policy continuity after Defense Minister Prabowo Subianto declared victory in Wednesday's presidential vote.

item.title: Pakistan’s Next Funding Review in Second Half of 2025, IMF Says
item.description: Pakistan has reaffirmed its commitment to fiscal consolidation and the International Monetary Fund will conduct its next funding review in the second half of this year, the multilateral agency said.
item.dc:creator: Ashutosh Joshi

media:content.media:description: A vendor arranges his wares at a market in Karachi, Pakistan, on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. Pakistan is scheduled to release consumer price index (CPI) figures on Dec 1. Photographer: Asim Hafeez/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Forces Switzerland to Question Its Love for Farmers
item.description: Switzerland’s bid for a US trade deal risks sparking a showdown with one political force at least as feisty as President Donald Trump: its own farmers.

item.description: President Donald Trump on Friday announced a partnership between United States Steel Corp. and Japan’s Nippon Steel Corp., shocking markets with an agreement he said would keep the once-iconic American firm in the US but otherwise providing no specifics.

item.title: Crypto Trader’s Convictions Vacated in Mango Markets Fraud Case
item.description: A trader charged in the first US case tied to cryptocurrency manipulation won a legal challenge to overturn his convictions for exploiting Mango Markets rules to steal $110 million from the exchange.

media:content.media:description: Cables connected to a mining rig at the Minto cryptocurrency mining center in Nadvoitsy, Russia, on Friday, Dec. 17, 2021. item.dc:creator: Emily Graffeo

item.title: Bessent: Could Get to 3% Growth by This Time Next Year | Wall Street Week
item.description: This week, US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent sat down with Wall Street Week's David Westin to talk about the administration's policies and its effect on markets and the economy. And, an inside look at how a company’s heritage can shape its future through innovation and preservation. Victoria Mars talks about Mars’ core principles and how they are applied even without the Mars family in management positions. Enel’s former CEO Francesco Starace discusses how he was able to move his company forward through technological change. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Tether Focuses Elsewhere While US Seeks to Regulate Stablecoins
item.description: While Congress is considering bills that would help integrate stablecoins more into mainstream finance, the largest issuer of the digital tokens says it will continue to focus on serving markets besides the US.
item.dc:creator: Teresa Xie, Michael P Regan

media:content.media:description: Paolo Ardoino, chief executive officer of Tether Holdings Ltd., during a Bloomberg Television interview in New York, US, on Friday, May 23, 2025. Ardoino discussed the US government’s decision to regulate stablecoins and what the GENIUS Act can do to help promote stablecoins.

item.title: Record £1.23bn Paid Out in Pet Insurance Claims in 2024
item.description: A record £1.23 billion was paid out in pet insurance claims in 2024, helping households cover the cost of veterinary treatment for unwell and injured animals, the Association of British Insurers (ABI) has said.

media:content.media:description: WARRINGTON, ENGLAND - JANUARY 04: A seven week old Daschund cross puppy waits to be re-homed at the Cheshire Dogs Home on January 4, 2010 in Warrington, England. The puppy is one of hundreds waiting for a new home at the Manchester and Cheshire Dogs Home and other animal shelters across Britain. There has been a huge surge in the number of abandoned pets over the Christmas and Winter period. (Photo by Christopher Furlong/Getty Images)
